Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 330 days, falling short by 37 days of the 1,095-day requirement within four years prior to application
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with minimum physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to clarify which test (physical presence or quality of attachment) was applied
Evidence_Used: Documentation submitted by applicant regarding residency and absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity in judicial assessment of evidence; request for additional documentation without explanation
Decision_Outcome: Application initially rejected by Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application refusal
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application; potential application of 'quality of attachment' test
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by failing to clearly identify the legal test used and provide adequate reasons for decision
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), subject to Federal Court review

Application_Facts: Rasaei was absent from Canada for 521 days during the four-year period preceding his application; Citizenship Judge assessed centralization of life using Koo factors
Residency_Compliance: Failed – did not meet three-year physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on alleged misinterpretation of residency test and failure to consider relevant evidence
Evidence_Used: Employment abroad, family ties in Canada, intention to return, travel records
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and allowance of appeal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo factors for assessing residence under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the Koo factors and concluded that Rasaei did not centralize his life in Canada during the relevant period

Application_Facts: Applicant was short by 67 days of required physical presence; considered factors such as property ownership and trips abroad
Residency_Compliance: Not compliant – insufficient physical presence and not normally resident
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted with reasonableness standard
Evidence_Used: Property ownership in Canada, travel history, duration of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of normal residency despite some ties to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on objective factors under Koo test
Remedy_Sought: Judicial overturn of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for normal residency
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship judge reasonably concluded applicant was not normally resident in Canada despite minor factual errors

Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Application_Facts: Applicant spent significant time abroad and lacked clear evidence of maintaining a Canadian residence
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Unclear reasoning by Citizenship Judge; reliance on 'information on file' without clarification; failure to resolve ambiguities
Evidence_Used: Notes referencing applicant's travel and residence history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear documentation or proof of maintained Canadian residence; ambiguous records
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remanded for reconsideration by a new Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residency in Canada within four years prior to application; exceptions for special circumstances under Federal Court jurisprudence
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable due to inadequate reasons and unresolved factual ambiguities

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence within four years prior to application
Application_Facts: Applicant provided education records, health records, and tax filings; lacked substantial employment or family ties in Canada; had US bank activity
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence and connection to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge did not consider full context of evidence
Evidence_Used: Education records, health records, tax filings, US bank activity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of employment records, limited family ties, gaps in physical presence documentation
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but residency connection questioned
Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of citizenship application due to insufficient proof of residency
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residency within four years prior to application under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by decontextualizing individual factors and failing to assess the totality of the evidence

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 551 days in the 4-year period preceding application
Owned businesses in Colombia
Traveled frequently between Canada and Colombia
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Appeal reviewed under reasonableness standard
Evidence_Used: Koo (Re) factors applied to assess centralization of mode of existence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate temporary nature of absences
Credibility_Assessment: Absences found to reflect a structural pattern, not temporary
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence test from Koo (Re)
Decision_Rationale: Frequent and prolonged absences from Canada
Significant personal and economic ties to Colombia
Pattern of absence inconsistent with residency requirement

Application_Facts: Applicant Li Zhang accumulated 922 days of residence in Canada within four years before application, falling short of the required 1095 days; residence established on October 2, 2002
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of residence days, application date, residency establishment date
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented days of physical residence
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or re-evaluation of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative and qualitative residency test under section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the law; no reviewable error found as applicant did not meet minimum 1095-day requirement

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act regarding 1095 days of physical presence
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed residency in Canada but could not provide sufficient evidence; relevant passport expired and destroyed
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and verifiable documentation to prove physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence led to uncertainty about claimed residency days
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or reinstatement of application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test: strict day-counting, qualitative assessment, or centralization of existence
Decision_Rationale: Judge correctly applied the physical presence test and reasonably concluded that the applicant failed to meet the 1095-day requirement due to lack of evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – Residency requirement
Application_Facts: Mr. Gunnarsson was present in Canada for 229 days and absent for 1231 days in the four years preceding his application; he did not centralize his life in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No – applicant failed to accumulate three years of residence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal of citizenship judge's decision on residency interpretation
Evidence_Used: Travel records, reasons for absence, frequency of visits, ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of habitual or centralized residence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on objective residency pattern
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of citizenship judge’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the applicant 'regularly, ordinarily, or customarily lives' in Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that Mr. Gunnarsson did not meet the residency requirement as he did not centralize his life in Canada despite maintaining some connections

Application_Facts: Mr. Mueller was absent for 1146 days and present for only 314 days during the four years preceding his application
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1095-day residency requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to adequately apply the Re Koo test and neglected key factors in analysis
Evidence_Used: Record of absences and presences in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of relevant factors under the Re Koo test
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Re Koo test for assessing residency
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge demonstrated a lack of understanding of the law and facts, leading to an unreasonable decision

Legal_Issue: Whether the appellant meets the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant accumulated 357 days of residence; no exceptions applied
Burden_of_Proof: On the appellant to demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Legal_Rule: Applicant must have at least three years (1,095 days) of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment by citizenship judge
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency due to studying abroad
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of days physically present in Canada: 357

Violation_Type: Failure to centralize mode of existence in Canada
Application_Facts: Mr. Chen was 31 days short of the required 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years; he made frequent trips abroad and lacked family or social ties in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the judge's decision-making process
Evidence_Used: Residency records, travel history, evidence of family and social ties (or lack thereof) in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of centralized life in Canada, insufficient days of physical residence
Credibility_Assessment: The judge found that Mr. Chen’s life was not centralized in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the citizenship judge's refusal of application
Remedy_Sought: Granting of Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test
Residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Mr. Chen did not meet the statutory residency requirement and failed to demonstrate that his life was centered in Canada
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission / Citizenship Judge, Federal Court on appeal

Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - residency requirement (3 years in Canada within 4 years preceding application)
Application_Facts: Cynthia Wall spent most of her time abroad as a missionary; only 38 days of physical presence in Canada over four years; maintained significant ties to Canada including taxes, medical insurance, and family
Residency_Compliance: Not met based on physical presence; claim based on 'centralized mode of living' and Koo guidelines
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to fully address the legal residency requirement; improper application of Koo's guidelines; confusion between recommendations and legal analysis
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of residency criteria despite evidence of ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside; case remanded for rehearing
Relief_Sought: Minister sought overturning of citizenship approval due to incorrect legal interpretation
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before the same Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under the Citizenship Act using Koo framework (combination of physical presence and centralized mode of living)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge did not properly apply the Koo guidelines and failed to provide adequate reasoning on whether residency requirement was met

Application_Facts: Mr. Chen was absent from Canada for 970 days, citing care for his ill mother and religious purposes
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet physical presence requirement; absences deemed structural and voluntary
Procedural_Issue: Alleged error in interpretation of residency requirement and failure to consider relevant criteria by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Duration and nature of absences, family ties, Koo factors, purpose of travel
Credibility_Assessment: Absences not found to be humanitarian; deemed voluntary
Outcome: Mr. Chen remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Granting of Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence in Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the residency requirements and considered relevant factors including Koo factors and nature of absences

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 58(1), Rule 61, IRPA sections related to refugee claim procedures
Governing_Law: Baker v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
Application_Facts: Jang family's PIF was submitted 7 days late; Board had valid contact information; contradictory notices issued by the Board
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide meaningful reasons for abandonment decision
Lack of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Standard form indicating late PIF submission
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explanation provided for abandonment despite available contact information
Insufficient justification for applying abandonment rule
Decision_Outcome: Claim declared abandoned by the Board
Outcome: Court set aside the Board's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the abandonment decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of abandonment issue by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Requirement for meaningful reasons in decisions of significant impact
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to provide adequate reasoning; contact information negated automatic abandonment; important decisions require substantive justification

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant challenged negative PRRA and H&C decisions citing procedural unfairness and incorrect assessments
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness breach did not affect outcome
Evidence_Used: hardship and child interests in H&C assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to provide new evidence rebutting prior IFA finding
Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed H&C application without undue reliance on impossibility standard
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions were reasonable and procedurally fair
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA and H&C decisions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for mixed fact/law issues
Correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: No new evidence to rebut IFA; procedural fairness breach inconsequential; H&C assessment balanced relevant factors

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed Pentecostal faith and detention in Eritrea; fled due to fear of persecution; held UNHCR refugee status; alleged risks due to illegal departure from Eritrea
Claimant_Status: Asylum seeker with UNHCR-recognized refugee status
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of credibility in applicant's testimony regarding religious practice and detention
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasons
Lack of transparency and intelligibility in decision
Breach of procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored UNHCR status
Did not assess risk from illegal exit from Eritrea
Insufficient justification for credibility findings
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding without sufficient basis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by visa officer
Outcome: Remitted for re-determination by different officer
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the visa officer’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Order for re-assessment of refugee claim
Declaration of unreasonable decision-making
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Procedural fairness
Burden and standard of proof in refugee claims
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked justification, failed to consider key evidence (UNHCR status), ignored potential grounds of persecution, and was not transparent or intelligible
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Violation_Type: Failure to provide sufficient proof of funds
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for permanent residence as a self-supporting Convention refugee
Failed to provide adequate proof of funds
Submitted incomplete and contradictory documents
Statutory declaration deemed insufficient by visa officer
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to meet financial and documentary requirements
Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with document submission requirements during application process
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of funds
Incomplete documentation
Lack of credible corroborating evidence
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of refusal decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to provide truthful answers and complete documentation under subsection 9(3)
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer did not err in law or fact; applicant failed to meet statutory obligations; contradictions and deficiencies undermined application credibility

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency obligation appeal with humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board committed an error of law or made a patently unreasonable finding of fact
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant faced credibility issues due to inconsistent explanations, employment records, and financial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28 - Residency obligations (730 days in 5 years)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Patently unreasonable finding by ignoring relevant evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly harsh assessment and dismissal of credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Permanent resident must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days in any five-year period
Crimes.Application_Factor: Conflicting evidence on residency and lifestyle as a loan shark
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a different Board member

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided conflicting evidence about presence in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in travel records, employment, and finances
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Immigration Appeal Division under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Overlooked bank statements and veterinary visits
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies in documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different Board member
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored relevant evidence and focused improperly on applicant's profession

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency determination with suspicion of financial misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board’s factual findings on residency
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting travel, employment, and financial evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Must be physically present in Canada for 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable rejection of evidence and credibility findings
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 28
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Provided documentation to support residency claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28, IRPA

Crimes.Violation_Type: Improper consideration of irrelevant factors in residency assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant engaged in loan sharking; Board used this to dismiss residency evidence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Disputed due to credibility and evidentiary issues
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper reliance on irrelevant conduct (loan sharking)
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board’s authority under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Relevant evidence dismissed due to applicant's profession
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively impacted by association with loan sharking, though unrelated to residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored credible evidence solely because of applicant's occupation

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta overstayed her visa, refugee claim was rejected, applied for H&C status based on family ties and best interests of the child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C application assessed internally without departure for permanent residence application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims within Canada despite requirement to apply from outside
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of exceptional hardship or compelling circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on sufficiency of evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that family support and financial stability mitigated hardship; no personal risk established in home country
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada as required by IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta sought exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada via H&C application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with expired status, failed refugee claimant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Attempt to obtain permanent residence without fulfilling procedural requirement to apply from outside Canada
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether officer had discretion to allow in-Canada H&C application despite statutory preference for out-of-country processing
Evidence_Used: Existence of family support in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of specific evidence demonstrating exceptional hardship or unique vulnerability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; decision based on insufficient proof, not credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably exercised discretion, found no compelling reasons to justify exemption; family and financial supports present

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Visa refusal based on credibility and admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can section 11 of the Act be a basis for visa refusal without specific inadmissibility findings?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 11(1) and 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's inconsistent statements and discrepancies with family testimonies undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent oral statements, conflicting family testimonies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 11(1) and Section 40(1)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Doubt about non-inadmissibility due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent and credible information
Crimes.Application_Factor: Credibility and consistency of applicant’s statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to answer truthfully as per section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Untruthful and evasive responses during interview
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 16(1) and 11(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent and vague responses regarding work history, family displacement, and LTTE involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant not credible due to inconsistencies and evasiveness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving non-inadmissibility due to lack of credibility

Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty of fairness in administrative decisions, Membership Code provisions on membership revocation
Application_Facts: Mr. Diabo was removed without notice or a hearing; Band Council lacked authority to revoke membership; procedural flaws in alternative remedies
Procedural_Issue: Lack of notice and opportunity to respond, absence of proper hearing
Jurisdictional_Issue: Band Council lacked authority to revoke membership under the Membership Code
Evidence_Used: Provisions of the Membership Code, procedural history of membership revocation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to support declaratory relief for earlier decisions
Decision_Outcome: Band Council's decision set aside, Mr. Diabo reinstated as member
Outcome: Membership reinstated, judicial review successful, costs to be determined
Relief_Sought: Reinstatement of membership, judicial review of Band Council decision
Remedy_Sought: Declaratory relief, reinstatement
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, correctness (implied by context of judicial review)
Decision_Rationale: Violation of procedural fairness, lack of authority under Membership Code, inadequacy of alternative remedies

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visa after a failed refugee claim; established life in Canada with family ties and community integration
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants, permanent residents not yet granted
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer did not consider pending sponsorship application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties in Canada, establishment in community, risks upon return to Guyana
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess impact of pending sponsorship application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected based on no unusual hardship found
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) consideration for permanent residence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of H&C application including sponsorship prospects
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual or disproportionate hardship required for exemption
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness for legal test errors
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship established; failure to consider sponsorship rendered decision unreasonable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after removal order issued; cited family ties, establishment, and country conditions in Guyana
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants under removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart after removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to consider the status and potential success of pending sponsorship application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family relationships in Canada, length of residence, integration, risk factors in Guyana
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis regarding likelihood of sponsorship approval as factor in hardship assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility not in dispute
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C relief denied due to absence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed on judicial review; matter referred for reassessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and Compassionate relief from removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by new PRRA officer considering sponsorship prospects
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of unusual or disproportionate hardship under H&C grounds
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness applicable if wrong legal test used
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Original decision unreasonable due to incomplete analysis of family reunification prospects via sponsorship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of natural justice principles or Charter rights in credibility assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to inconsistent statements and implausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Authority of visa officers to assess Convention refugee claims overseas
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Application_Factor: Overseas location of applicant affecting procedural rights

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Credibility and truthfulness requirements
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Iraq with inconsistencies in details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in decision-making
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer authority over overseas applicants
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, consistent evidence supporting persecution claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to contradictions and implausibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn visa officer's rejection of refugee claim
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted within discretion and followed proper procedures
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa officer at Canadian diplomatic mission abroad

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Samuel overstayed his visa in Canada.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence or work permit
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies between application and FOSS notes used to question credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to raise issues during hearing, violating procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of the Immigration Appeal Division to assess character based on pardoned convictions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: FOSS notes, application forms, police reports
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on unverified police reports and incorrect factual assertions (e.g., son's birth year)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment based on inconsistencies and omissions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa denied due to character concerns
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act; procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Improper reliance on pardoned convictions and failure to disclose key issues

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of pardoned convictions and unproven allegations to impugn character
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Decision dismissed due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessed as lacking credibility due to inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application forms, FOSS notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements and omissions in immigration application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to notify applicant of issues affecting decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Omissions and discrepancies in application versus official records
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and reliability of evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Pardon under Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Adverse characterization of pardoned offenses is prohibited
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies between Mr. Samuel's account and documentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit eligibility and character assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reliance on pardoned convictions and unverified police reports
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Criminal Records Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Perceived lack of remorse due to false statements and non-testification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application data, internal notes

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Past convictions and alleged false statements despite pardon
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of erroneous facts (son’s birth year) and unverified reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and admissibility of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Pardoned convictions cannot negatively affect character assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to disclose relevant issues during hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: False Statements in Application for Permanent Residence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in using application omissions against applicant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: FOSS notes and application discrepancies used without disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act prohibits adverse use of pardons
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and misuse of pardoned record
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Decision found unreasonable and set aside
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – government body did not respond adequately to procedural flaws
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Non-Canadian spouse with prior deportation history
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high due to nature of offense and re-entry attempt
Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety and family unit integrity
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to reliance on untested police reports
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, application statements, FOSS notes
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low – police reports not corroborated by testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative – based on failure to testify and inconsistent accounts
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5 of the Criminal Records Act, IRPA provisions on criminal inadmissibility

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Mexico; contradictions in testimony; lacked evidence; moved internally but did not seek local protection or prove inability to relocate safely
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging credibility and internal flight alternative findings
Evidence_Used: Panel's assessment of internal relocation options
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony
Lack of supporting documentation
Failure to demonstrate inability to access protection internally
Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Decision_Outcome: Asylum claim dismissed by Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Panel's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for factual findings
Correctness standard for jurisdictional issues
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and internal flight alternative were reasonable based on record and applicable law

Legal_Provision_Violated: Duty of Fairness in Administrative Decision-Making
Application_Facts: Officer contacted Wu's employer without disclosing the communication or its contents to Wu
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose information used in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of opportunity for applicant to respond to new evidence
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of case to a different officer for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer violated procedural fairness by relying on undisclosed information, depriving Wu of the right to respond

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and prospective fear
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD's assessment found unreasonable due to factual errors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on systemic corruption and ineffective enforcement in Mexico
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and threats from former employer in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate state protection despite legal reforms
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider contradictory evidence on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of systemic corruption and lack of enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal risk due to gender-based violence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new panel

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of domestic abuse and ongoing threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No recent direct contact from perpetrator
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of abusive behavior by perpetrator
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and history of violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to gender and prior victimization
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, country condition reports, police records
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and consistent with documentary evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD’s rejection deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with protection obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to fear of abduction by abusive husband and former employer
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to address evidence of systemic failures
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient consideration of state protection gaps

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated threats and history of abuse
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Lack of recent incidents cited by RPD
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of coercive and threatening behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – threats of death and bodily harm
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on past relationship and gender
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Chronic abuse and failure of authorities to intervene
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of protective laws in theory
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic lack of protection for women
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – as a woman facing domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical records, police reports
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and supported by country conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD error in dismissal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in corrupt systems
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD selectively used evidence on anti-corruption efforts
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account consistent with systemic issues
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be both available and effective
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Ineffective state response due to corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Reports on corruption in Mexican law enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection exists due to legal reforms
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: RPD dismissed claim without proper evaluation of evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: RPD has authority but must act fairly
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence of judicial inefficacy
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to properly assess state protection

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution from FARC in Colombia
Procedural_Issue: Lack of oral hearing despite credibility being central to decision
Evidence_Used: Officer acknowledged FARC's human rights violations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by applicant to establish credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's credibility; credibility was central to the decision
Relief_Sought: Procedural fairness in pre-removal risk assessment
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness; reasonableness for fact-driven determinations
Decision_Rationale: Oral hearing required when credibility is at issue; absence constituted procedural error
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer conducting pre-removal risk assessment

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Application_Facts: Ms. Kettani applied for Canadian citizenship; Minister challenged her compliance with residency requirements
Residency_Compliance: Citizenship judge found that Ms. Kettani met the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under section 22.1 of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents, answers to questions during hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in evidence noted but resolved by credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found Ms. Kettani credible despite some inconsistencies
Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review; decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Minister sought to set aside the citizenship judge’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the citizenship judge’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The judge properly applied the law, assessed credibility, and made reasonable findings based on evidence
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge under the Citizenship Act

Violation_Type: Misinterpretation and improper application of statutory provision
Application_Facts: Jiminez suffered severe persecution in El Salvador; Board dismissed claim based on changed country conditions without assessing atrocity of past persecution
Claimant_Status: Asylum seeker claiming Convention refugee status
Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from previous persecution under s. 2(3)
Evidence_Used: Evidence of past persecution, psychological effects
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Psychological effects dismissed without linking to nature of persecution
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, found error in Board's analysis
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Board decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) regarding compelling reasons from previous persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board erred by failing to consider whether persecution was sufficiently appalling or atrocious under s. 2(3)
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant sought refugee status, which was denied twice by the same PRRA Officer.
Procedural_Issue: Alleged bias due to same officer handling both applications; procedural fairness concerns under natural justice
Evidence_Used: PRRA application materials, credibility assessments, officer's findings
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility assessment reviewed for reasonableness; court found no error in assessment
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA decision based on alleged bias and credibility errors
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Principles of natural justice and impartiality
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of bias; credibility assessment was reasonable and within acceptable limits

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Information under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether Ms. Abdallah's non-disclosure constituted misrepresentation under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was Ms. Abdallah's failure to disclose the June 21 Call a misrepresentation under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, IAD's decision set aside, appeal remanded for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Abdallah believed the Embassy's message might be an error or prank, but she had knowledge of the communication
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Communication from Embassy regarding sponsorship withdrawal, testimony about awareness and intent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding material information that could induce error in immigration administration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose regardless of personal belief in accuracy of information
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), later reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: IAD incorrectly applied exception for honest and reasonable belief
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether the omission could induce error in the administration of the Act
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: IAD initially failed to consider the duty to disclose despite uncertainty
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of withheld information and potential to mislead immigration authorities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Knowledge of sponsorship withdrawal attempt and decision not to disclose
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination due to legal and factual errors

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation through omission of material facts
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Abdallah was informed of sponsorship withdrawal and ceased communication with spouse, yet entered Canada without disclosure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Sponsorship applicant seeking entry to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entry made without full disclosure affecting admissibility
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Withholding material information that could influence immigration decision
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Initial finding of inadmissibility overturned on appeal, then challenged via judicial review
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of federal immigration law by administrative tribunal and court
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Embassy call records, border entry statements, testimony on awareness and intent
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation or explanation provided at time of entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistent actions despite knowledge of potential inadmissibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD’s decision overturned; case remanded for re-evaluation
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal will be re-evaluated by another IAD member
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Allowance of sponsorship application and entry to Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the omission constitutes misrepresentation under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Withholding material facts constitutes misrepresentation regardless of actual sponsorship status
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Appeal Division, subject to Federal Court oversight

Violation_Type: Procedural unfairness, Improper assessment of evidence
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk due to military draft evasion
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not provide an oral hearing; used rejected evidence to discredit new evidence
Evidence_Used: Evidence related to military draft evasion
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by applicant to support risk claim
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility was not seriously questioned; officer unreasonably used prior rejection to discredit new evidence
Remedy_Sought: Case remitted to a different officer for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: New evidence standard under PRRA regulations
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was unreasonable due to improper use of evidence and lack of procedural fairness

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to adequately consider targeted nature of risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk was not generalized given repeated targeting by police

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought exemption from deportation based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Applicant not informed of concerns about marriage bona fides and denied opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in file not disclosed to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts raised about marriage bona fides
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from s. 9(1) based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Balance of probabilities should have been used
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Denial based on unsubstantiated doubts without procedural fairness

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant denied exemption from applying for landed immigrant status outside Canada due to alleged marriage fraud
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant except for marriage legitimacy concern

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to disclose specific contradictions to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage deemed not bona fide based on undisclosed concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on incorrect legal standard and lack of procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged misrepresentation regarding marriage bona fides
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper application of standard of proof in assessing misrepresentation

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions concerning misrepresentation in immigration applications

Crimes.Application_Error: Use of criminal standard of proof in civil matter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balance of probabilities should have been applied
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correct legal standard and procedural fairness required on redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly found, but allegations of misrepresentation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged immigration fraud through invalid marriage claim

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balance of probabilities is correct standard

Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Legality and procedural fairness reviewed by court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements in an immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer had authority to assess genuineness of employment offer based on applicant's credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; officer's decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility due to false statements about how he found the job and his relationship with the employer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions requiring truthful answers and authorizing refusal based on lack of credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False information provided during interview regarding relationship with employer
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of applicant credibility affecting assessment of job offer genuineness
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing false information in application and interview
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Officer's reasonable grounds to doubt truthfulness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Truthfulness and consistency of applicant's statements
Crimes.Authority: Visa officer has jurisdiction to assess overall application legitimacy including credibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer exceeded jurisdiction by reassessing employment offer genuineness
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no breach of duty found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided inconsistent information about meeting the employer in 2001
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation and officer authority to assess credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inconsistent information provided about relationship with employer
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility concerns leading to doubt about genuineness of employment offer
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing inconsistent and untruthful information during interview
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Officer's authority to assess credibility even when HRSDC validated job offer
Crimes.Application_Factor: Consistency and plausibility of applicant's narrative
Crimes.Authority: Officer acted within jurisdiction to question application legitimacy based on credibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Fraudulent misrepresentation in public service appointment process
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over validity of public service appointment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PSC was functus officio and whether promissory estoppel applied
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Courts Act, principles of administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of false educational credentials provided by applicant
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate invalidity of PSC's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's submission of fraudulent documents undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Doctrines of functus officio and promissory estoppel
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged finality of first PSC decision and alleged promise of continued employment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: PSC's second decision upheld as clarificatory, not a new decision
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: False educational credentials, text of PSC decisions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law, public service integrity framework
Crimes.Defendant_Response: PSC maintained authority to clarify its decision
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside PSC’s second decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Revocation of public service appointment due to fraud
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute concerning revocation of appointment based on fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PSC was functus officio and whether promissory estoppel barred revocation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act, administrative law doctrines
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of falsified education credentials and intent behind PSC decisions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show error in PSC’s corrective action
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 69 of Public Service Employment Act; functus officio doctrine
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim that second decision was ultra vires and promissory estoppel applied
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: PSC authorized to clarify original decision; no estoppel established
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: False academic records, wording of PSC decisions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Public service integrity and administrative accountability
Crimes.Defendant_Response: PSC acted within statutory authority to correct fraud
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Setting aside of PSC’s second decision
Crimes.Outcome: Dismissal of application, upholding of PSC’s decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 69, Public Service Employment Act

Legal_Provision: s. 2(e) of the Canadian Bill of Rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false or misleading statements in a passport application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons for denying a passport application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Passport Canada did not adequately assess credibility or contradictions in statements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 10(2)(b) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis of evidence and legal standards by decision maker
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to analyze contradictions and legal elements such as consent
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in applicant's statements, context of alleged false information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement for clear, transparent, and justifiable administrative reasoning
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and completeness of information in passport application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of identity document without lawful excuse
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Justification for denial based on possession of another’s passport
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Code, s. 56.1; Canadian Passport Order, s. 10(2)(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No proper assessment of applicant's explanation for possession
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Physical possession of another person's passport at U.S. border
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 56.1 of the Criminal Code and s. 10(2)(b) of the Canadian Passport Order
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Possession of another individual's passport without lawful excuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis regarding consent and use of applicant’s own passport in offense
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to address key legal elements such as consent under s. 56.1
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness and compliance with procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanation for possessing the document, context of border encounter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on decision maker to justify denial with reasoned analysis
Crimes.Application_Factor: Link between possession of foreign document and misuse of passport services
